topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the episode’s focus on building power and influence, previews Pfeffer’s “Seven Rules of Power,” and frames the conversation as a realistic guide to career advancement even if it feels uncomfortable.

topics.title: Why power feels uncomfortable, why it matters
topics.summary: Pfeffer explains research linking political skill to promotions, pay, and lower stress, and argues discomfort comes from confusing power as a tool with unethical uses of it. They discuss why underrepresented groups especially benefit from learning power skills.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Uizard and Webflow.

topics.title: Being less judgmental to build influence
topics.summary: Pfeffer explains why his class “is not for everyone” and why suspending judgment is essential when you need others’ cooperation. He emphasizes relationship-building, emotional control, and not telegraphing disrespect.

topics.title: Seven Rules overview and Doing Power practice
topics.summary: They outline the Seven Rules of Power and discuss Pfeffer’s “Doing Power” assignments designed to close the knowing-doing gap. Pfeffer shares an extreme example of a student leveraging the project into major political and government roles.

topics.title: Rule: Build a powerful personal brand
topics.summary: Pfeffer argues visibility is required for advancement and gives examples (consulting, VC, startups) of differentiating through projects, content, events, and distinctive presence. They discuss balancing substance with visibility and reframing self-promotion as amplifying impact.

topics.title: Rule: Get out of your own way
topics.summary: They cover how discomfort, imposter syndrome, and excessive apologizing undermine perceived competence and authority. Pfeffer stresses prioritizing performance and respect over being liked, using examples from high-stakes professions.

topics.title: Rule: Break the rules to stand out
topics.summary: Pfeffer explains rule-breaking as a way to become memorable and disrupt systems designed for incumbents, including the simple but powerful act of asking for what you want. Jason Calacanis is discussed as an example of unconventional career and investing tactics.

topics.title: Rule: Network relentlessly (and generously)
topics.summary: Networking is reframed as generosity and usefulness—introducing people, sharing resources, and building broad connections to gain non-redundant knowledge. Pfeffer shares Omid Kordestani’s story of networking into Google and offers practical exercises to meet key people.

topics.title: Weak ties and brokerage as networking strategy
topics.summary: They discuss why weak ties provide better job leads and novel information (Granovetter’s research) and why becoming a connector/broker increases influence. Pfeffer gives examples of connecting experts and funders as a value-creating power move.

topics.title: Rule: Use your power to get more power
topics.summary: Pfeffer explains the self-reinforcing loop: using authority to deliver results attracts resources, opportunities, and allies. They touch on how visible power signals draw followers and set up a transition into appearing powerful.

topics.title: Rule: Show up in a powerful fashion
topics.summary: They explore how appearance, voice, and body language shape perceived power more than content, with examples from corporate crises and Steve Jobs’ coached transformation. Pfeffer lists practical tactics (eye contact, no notes, posture, volume, proximity) and emphasizes these are learnable skills.
